thread.title: Year-round runway could be built on Antarctica
thread.title_full: Year-round runway could be built on Antarctica

title: Year-round runway could be built on Antarctica
text:
Map: Antarctica 
Exploration could be about to take off with the Australian Antarctic Division investigating a new year-round runway site on the icy continent. 
Currently access to Australian research stations on the continent via the skies is limited to an ice-runway that is only usable during certain months of the year. 
"The reason that we are looking for year-round aviation is not only the support to our expeditioners, but it allows us to branch out into different science experiments that we haven't been able to do in the past," project manager Bryce Harris said. 
The project team are exploring two different potential sites in the Vestfold Hills near Davis Station, one in the Heidemann Valley and the other up on a ridge. 
"In one site we've got a valley filled with glacial sediments and we're characterising those different sediments and the different environments, up (on the ridge) we are looking at a rocky site and we're looking at a veneer of the glacial sediment sitting over the top of the rock," geologist Alistair Reed said. 
The Vestfold Hills are an anomaly in the Antarctic — they are a range of mountains and glacial lakes rarely covered in snow and ice. The gravel, sandy landscape is a remnant of the eastern glacier. Photo: This ridge is one of two potential runway sites near Davis Station in Antarctica. (Supplied: Bryce Harris) 
High on the ridge site, geologists are in uncharted territory. 
"We've had a station here for more than 60 years and really this part of the Vestfold Hills hasn't been mapped in very much detail at all," Dr Reed said. 
"So we are creating that base layer of information so that it is exactly right." 
Over summer a team of eight people, including geologists and surveyors, has been drilling for core samples of rock and soil. Photo: The Australian Antarctic Division's team of geologists and engineers at the "ridge site" near Davis Station. (Supplied: Ben Jones) 
"We are actually exploring what is beneath the surface," Dr Reed said. 
"So as a geologist we can map the surface and we can relate what we see at surface to what we know of the glacial processes that took place in the Vestfold Hills. 
"With the drilling we are looking at what took place under the surface and ultimately, should the government decide to put a runway in the Vestfold Hills, that's what is going to be supporting the runway surface itself." 
The Vestfold Hills have been looked at before as a potential runway site, but it has never got past the concept stage. Photo: Geologist Alistair Reed at the Heidemann Valley, Vestfold Hills in East Antarctica. (Supplied: Ben Jones) 
It cannot come soon enough for some expeditioners whose science is constrained by the tight summer transport window. 
Wilkins Aerodrome is the only air link between Australia and Antarctica, a crucial piece of infrastructure supporting expeditioners at Davis, Casey, and Mawson Stations — but it is not always reliable. Photo: Engineering supervisor Bryce Harris in Heidemann Valley. (Supplied: Alistair Reed) 
"What we are constrained by at the moment is the summer season and being able to get people in and out," Mr Harris said. 
"When we look at Wilkins we don't necessarily get to use it in that late December to January period." 
As soon as temperatures rise above zero at Wilkins, the surface can melt and intercontinental flights in and out are cancelled. 
"When you've got the solar radiation hitting that (ice runway), you get a sheen, surface melt, the wind also has an impact on it," runway manager Jeff Hadley said. 
"It polishes the ice and gets near impossible to measure the friction. It becomes quite treacherous for aircraft landing on it." 
The Wilkins Runway is open in November, December and February — a short transport window. 
"The reason that we are looking for year-round aviation is not only the support to our expeditioners but it allows us to branch out into different science experiments that we haven't been able to in the past," Mr Harris said. Photo: The drill working in the Heidemann Valley, Vestfold Hills in East Antarctica. (Supplied: Alistair Reed) 
Elephant seal researcher Clive McMahon knows what it is like to be under time pressure, to fit research into that small window of time. 
He is waiting for molting elephant seals to arrive at the wallow near Davis Station so they can be caught and fitted with an ocean sensor. 
It is a tortuous wait — the elephant seals are slow to come and Dr McMahon is hoping to attach 20 sensors before he is forced to leave on the ship Aurora Australis in mid-February. 
"It is a bit tricky, we rely on the ship to take us home because that is essentially the last exit from Davis Station," Dr Clive McMahon said. 
"So that makes it a little difficult because it puts us working against a time barrier, and you know it's still quite early in the season for many of the animals down here at the end of February." 
Any air link through to Eastern Antarctica would likely be an aviation hub providing greater intercontinental flights as well as greater access to more deep-field science. 
Countries that have stations nearby — India, Russia and China — are also likely to be interested in using any new runway.
